author: Special Correspondent
text:
Products manufactured by them are of high quality: Mayor

Products made by self-help groups (SHGs) were of high quality, matching some of the private brands, said Mayor V.V. Rajan Chellappa here on Wednesday.

Presenting cheques to the tune of Rs. 4.21 crore, in the form of revolving fund with subsidy, to 461 women SHGs, he said that an SHG, Sakti Balaji, had bagged bulk orders to supply paper cups/plates to Tirumala-Tirupati Devasthanam. “Because of the high quality of products and competitive pricing, the SHGs not only survived but also stood on top,” he said, and assured that the Corporation of Madurai would extend all support to them.

Providing infrastructure and according technical training under National Urban Livelihood Mission had helped many women SHGs rise up to the expectations of consumers. Despite stiff competition, the SHGs were able to survive because of the quality of goods, Mr. Rajan Chellappa said, adding the bakery units run by them in the city were doing brisk business.

At a time when many MPs were fighting for 33 per cent reservation for women in Parliament, seven of the 12 Municipal Corporations in Tamil Nadu were headed by women Mayors. Similarly, 40 of the 100 councillors of Madurai Corporation were women, he noted.

Deputy Mayor K. Thiraviam, Deputy Commissioner S. Shanthi, City Health Officer Yasoda Mani, zone chairmen, councillors and officials also spoke on the occasion.

The beneficiaries said that the revolving fund had come as a motivation for their good work. It ranged from Rs. 10,000 to Rs. 50,000 for each group. A few other SHGs, which received loans, coupled with subsidy, for expansion of their products, thanked the Corporation.
title: 461 SHGs get Rs 4.21 crore as revolving fund
